description: This figure displays visual comparisons of image reconstruction results using DMPlug and several other methods across different inverse problems (IPs). caption: Figure 2: Evolution of the data-fitting loss ||y - A(x)||2 of our DMPlug method vs. SOTA methods over percentage progress, for noiseless nonlinear deblurring on the CelebA dataset. Here, the percentage progress is calculated with respect to the total number of iterations taken by each method. The shadow regions indicate the ranges of the loss over 50 instances.
description: This figure shows a comparison of the data-fitting loss across different iterations for a noiseless nonlinear deblurring task using the CelebA dataset.  The plot compares the proposed DMPlug method to other state-of-the-art methods, showing the decrease in loss over the percentage of progress in the iterative process. caption: Figure 3: Interleaving methods (left) vs. our DMPlug method (right) for solving IPs using pretrained DMs. While interleaving methods cannot ensure the feasibility of the final estimate for either the object manifold M or the feasible set {x|y = A(x)}, our DMPlug method ensures the manifold feasibility while promoting y ≈ A(x) through global optimization.
description: The figure compares two methods for solving inverse problems using pretrained diffusion models. The left side shows the traditional interleaving methods, which struggle to guarantee that the final result is both on the object manifold and satisfies the measurement constraint. The right side shows the DMPlug method, which views the reverse diffusion process as a function that maps from the seed space to the object manifold, effectively resolving both manifold and measurement feasibility issues.

caption: Figure 4: Comparison of prevailing interleaving methods and our plug-in method
description: The figure compares prevailing interleaving methods and the proposed plug-in method.  Interleaving methods iteratively alternate between reverse diffusion steps in a diffusion model and steps to satisfy measurement constraints. This process is shown to lack guarantees on both manifold feasibility (the generated image looks natural) and measurement feasibility (the image satisfies the measurement constraints). The plug-in method, in contrast, treats the reverse diffusion process as a function and optimizes a single objective function encompassing both manifold and measurement feasibility, leading to more reliable results. Algorithm 1 and Algorithm 2 illustrate the difference in the approaches, with Algorithm 1 representing the interleaving methods and Algorithm 2 representing the plug-in method.

caption: Figure 5: PSNR (dB) vs. per-iteration wall-clock time (s) running on an NVIDIA A100, for various reverse steps in R. Experiments on CelebA for 4× super-resolution; solver: ADAM; maximum iterations: 6,000
description: The figure shows the PSNR (peak signal-to-noise ratio) performance of the DMPlug method against the Resample (SOTA) method for various reverse steps (3, 5, 7, 11, 15) in the DDIM (denoising diffusion implicit model) reverse process.  The experiment was conducted on the CelebA dataset for 4x super-resolution using the ADAM optimizer and running for a maximum of 6000 iterations. The x-axis represents the per-iteration wall-clock time (seconds) on an NVIDIA A100 GPU, and the y-axis represents the PSNR (dB).  It demonstrates that a small number of reverse steps (such as 3) is sufficient for DMPlug to outperform Resample.

caption: Figure 8: (1) The spectral bias of DMPlug with the ADAM solver [47]. (2) The spectral bias of DMPlug with the L-BFGS solver [75]. The IP we experiment with here is regression against a noisy image with Gaussian noise at σ = 0.08, i.e., the same denoising problem as in Fig. 6 (2).
description: This figure visualizes the spectral bias of the DMPlug method using two different optimizers, ADAM and L-BFGS.  Spectral bias refers to the faster learning of low-frequency components compared to high-frequency components. The plots show the frequency-band errors (FBEs) over iterations for five frequency bands, revealing a clear trend of faster learning in lower frequency bands. This spectral bias is linked to the ELTO (early-learning-then-overfitting) phenomenon observed in the method.
